stream_context.summary: Kaze works on Course 15 (space/factory stage), focusing first on reflective building textures and then brainstorming the entire mutated-Yoshi boss fight. Most of the stream alternates between shader/texture tweaks and a long design jam about how the boss and arena should work.

development_findings.summary: Initial reflective-wall idea (small star texture over black) looked “terrible.” Kaze experimented with i4/i8 textures, brightness, additive combiner tricks, and finally adopted a large square-grid texture supplied by chat, which gave the desired moving-reflection effect.
development_findings.quote: That’s way nicer than what I had before, but why? I don’t understand why this is better.

development_findings.summary: Graphics of the space level were overhauled again during the week because previous art was judged ugly.

Engine optimisations allow 480i on real hardware; with the same tweaks, other decomp projects like LR64 could also run 480i. Game targets 30 fps and currently renders ~4 000 triangles; Expansion Pak is required for performance.
development_findings.quote: My game takes full advantage of the optimisations, so obviously you would be able to run it at 480i without too much trouble.

development_findings.summary: Public demo shipped with only Course 1 to gather physics & camera feedback; survey results were "very useful."
development_findings.quote: The purpose of the demo is to get feedback on Mario's physics and the camera, so putting more in distracts from the purpose.

development_findings.summary: Next major task is designing the Course 15 boss: a giant, mutated Yoshi that teleports via black holes, causes shock-wave ground pounds, spits acid puddles, and may roll into a ball. Player defeats it by destroying pulsating tumour-growths, effectively healing rather than killing it.
development_findings.quote: What if you just destroy the tumors and that makes him happy and he's like, 'Wow, thanks for helping me.'

development_findings.summary: Mutated baby Yoshis will roam the level. Each has a single growth; stomping it cures them, they gain pupils, do a happy animation, drop coins, and vanish through a mini black hole.
Player will always remain regular Mario; no mechs or form changes. Legacy wing cap stays; metal cap rejected because it ‘acts like a key.’ New caps in hack are ice, cloud and bomb.
development_findings.quote: One important ground rule is that most of the time you will stay Mario with the same physics—that’s important to me.

development_findings.summary: Kaze refuses to port the project to the PC build of SM64 despite community pressure, choosing to stay pure N64.
development_findings.quote: People have been so insistent about the PC port that out of pure stubbornness I want nothing to do with it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed repeated frustration when graphics experiments failed but showed visible relief when a solution worked.
He worries the second YouTube channel is growing too much, calling it “too private for the public.”
context_findings.quote: I'm a little scared that there's too many people watching my second channel because it's just like me posting whatever the fuck I feel like.

context_findings.summary: Strong annoyance toward constant PC-port requests; likens it to strangers asking him daily to do Formula 1 racing.
context_findings.quote: Imagine you drive a car and every day people ask, ‘Why aren’t you doing Formula 1?’—that's what the PC-port talk feels like.

context_findings.summary: States the project isn’t about money; motivation is making a cool N64 game.
context_findings.quote: I don't think it really matters what I do. I'm not in it for the money anyway; I just want to make a cool N64 game.

biobak.summary: Collaborated off-stream on boss; wants a ‘tentacle Yoshi’ and supplied concept art.
biobak.quote: I'm 100 % down for a tentacle Yoshi.

key_stories.title: Reflection Texture Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent over an hour failing to make a reflective skyscraper wall look good. Chat user Asa provided a large square-grid texture; doubling its scale finally produced an attractive result.
key_stories.challenge: Original star-based reflection looked noisy and banded.
key_stories.process: Tried brightness tweaks, i4→i8 swap, additive combiner changes, larger texture tiles; accepted Asa’s grid and enlarged squares.
key_stories.outcome: Texture now ‘a million times better’; serves as template for other buildings.
key_stories.key_quote: That's way nicer than what I had before… I don't like that it's better, but I'm happy with it.

key_stories.title: Pivot to Healing the Boss
key_stories.summary: Initial idea was to kill a grotesque, tentacled Yoshi. Mid-discussion, Kaze flips the concept: Mario cures its tumours instead, turning enemy into ally.
key_stories.challenge: Wanted a memorable boss fight without feeling derivative of Gooper Blooper.
key_stories.process: Brain-stormed attacks (tongues, acid, teleports), arena layout, and enemy minions; questioned moral angle of killing baby Yoshis.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on ‘cure, don't kill’ mechanic—destroy growths, Yoshi turns green again, thanks Mario and exits via black hole.
key_stories.key_quote: What if you destroy the tumors and that like makes him happy… that’s a banger idea.

key_stories.title: Refusal to Embrace the PC Port
key_stories.summary: Community keeps demanding a PC-port version; Kaze digs in his heels, explaining philosophical and emotional reasons for staying on original hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Persistent viewer pressure to move development to SM64 PC port/ex-co-op.
key_stories.process: Uses F1 racing analogy; recounts being mocked online; voices distrust of buzz around PC builds.
key_stories.outcome: Publicly commits to N64 target only; acknowledges financial upside but rejects it.
key_stories.key_quote: Out of pure stubbornness I want nothing to do with it—even if I could see a use case.
